post.title: Write react components in typescript - a model component
post.content:
Writing react component in typescript makes your code easily maintainable because your components would be aware of props they would have knowledge on what props they would need while you use them, you will have to pass the same set of props to them, they won't allow unwanted props and would show error message in your editor.

Here is an example of the building block of a typescript react component.

import React, { FunctionComponent } from 'react'

interface CardProps {
    price: number,
    addToWishlist: () => void,
    isAvailable?: boolean
}

const Card: FunctionComponent<CardProps> = (props) => {
    const {
        price,
        addToWishlist,
        isAvailable
    } = props;
    return (
        <div>
            Price {price}
            <button onClick={addToWishlist}>Add to wishlist</button>
            {
                isAvailable &&
                "Available"
            }

        </div>
    )
}

export default Card;

 And import it like below:

<Card price={price} addToWishlist={addToWishlist} />

 

As you can see, this component is showing the price, has a function to add the item to the wishlist, and has one optional prop -- location. Here the location prop is optional. You not necessarily need to pass it as props while you import this component. 

We are using the interface here for named type objects. Simply say -- An interface declaration is a name for the object type. This object type will have definition details of all the props a component would need in order to use it.

FunctionComponent is a generic type provided by the react official typings. It allows for optional child components. Render children like below:

{ children }

So while your component has these features you would not worry that your component would get unwanted props because it would not allow them.

The component is tightly coupled with props. And that is what makes this component a great component. It is a fine piece of code.

You should be aware of Typescript - Types feature. These are the most common features that you require for react components.  Though typeScript provides data types as a part of its optional Type System, if you chose to use types then you need to declare them. The data type classification is as given below −

  1. array
    Array<number>, Array<string>, Array[object]
    or
    number[], string[], object[],

  2. The primitives: string, number and boolean
    string, number, boolean

  3. object Types
    object

  4. any
    TypeScript also has a special type, any, that you can use whenever you don’t want a particular value to cause type-checking errors.
    any

  5. void
    Use void when return is not required. This is useful when you don't want to return any output from functions.
    void

  6. null and undefined
    JavaScript has two primitive values used to signal absent or uninitialized values: null and undefined.
    null, undefined 

  7. Interface
    An interface declaration is a name for the object type
    interface Point {
    x: number;
    y: number;
}

     

  8. Type Aliases
    A type alias is a name for any type. we can use the same type more than once and refer to it by a single name. You can also use Type Aliases in place of interface for react component.The syntax for a type alias is:
    type Point = {
    x: number;
    y: number;
};
     
    Almost all features of an interface are available in type, the key distinction is that a type cannot be re-opened to add new properties vs an interface that is always extendable.

  9. Union
    TypeScript’s type system allows you to build new types out of existing ones using a large variety of operators. This feature of typescript is called union. When you not the sure type of variable you can allow multiple types like below:

    let id: number | string;

So now you know the basic building block of the typescript react component and the Typescript Types it would require, you would be able to create the bigger and complex component now. You can refer to the building block and base component that is written in the beginning of the post.
post.desc: Learn writing react component in typescript and make your code easily maintainable. Write light and clean react
post.creator: 605e9abb31180b0015fcb826
